bibl.title: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to George A. Kellogg, March 14, 1941

div1.p: Hench requests copies of Mabel Lazear's photographs and discusses Agramonte's daughter. He recommends taking sketches of the "Cuban versions" of the painting rather than the originals to Cuba with him.

div1.head: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to George A. Kellogg, March 14, 1941
div1.opener:
March 14, 1941
Mr. George A. Kellogg
257 Cornelison Ave.
Jersey City, N. J.
My dear Mr. Kellogg:
div1.p:
Mrs. Lazear kindly sent me a copy of her letter to you, and I am delighted
to see that she is so interested and plans to be so cooperative. May I hasten to ask
you a real favor. I understand you will be making photographic copies of Mrs. Lazear's
pictures of Dr. Lazear. Some months ago I made a similar request of her, but the re-
quest got lost in our correspondence, and I wondered if you would please have an extra
copy made of the photographs and let me have them. I shall be glad to pay what is
necessary. I am also delighted at General Truby's interest, and I am sure he will be
very helpful.

I have just had a letter from Dr. Agramonte's daughter, Mrs. Rodriguez-Leon.
You will remember that she is rather bitter about the whole affair because her father
was caught between two fires. He was more or less slighted by the Americans and con-
sidered a traitor to Finlay by the Cubans. Nevertheless, I think you should know what
she says about the sketches. I am therefore enclosing a copy of her letter. I am sure
that despite her present attitude she will be glad to do what she can for you. She is
a most intelligent and charming young woman and one very well worthy of having on one's
side.

I will be leaving for Florida next Friday, and from Palm Beach to Havana on
the twenty-first. My address will be the Villa Atlantique Hotel, Palm Beach, Florida.
I am still a little worried that I have not yet received the various data that I gave
you. I understood you wanted them only for a short time and would have some copied,
merely showing Mr. Cornwell the others. If you are through with them, I would certainly
like to have them back before leaving. Also, you haven't yet sent me a signed Osler
painting, and I wondered whether you were able to accede to my request to have the pre-
liminary sketches (that is, the Cuban version) photographed. As I wrote you, if you
really want me to exhibit the actual Cuban versions, I will do so, but in view of the
fact that you aren't planning to do much with them, I wondered whether we would be adding
insult to injury by showing them to the Cubans and then having you come out with another
version very shortly. I think your purposes could be served by merely giving me adequate
representations, that is, a 5 x 7 or 8 x 10 black and white photograph of the sketches.
I could then show these to Mr. Moran, Dr. Agramonte's daughter and others who might give
me help regarding the uniforms, size of figures, facial expressions, etc.
div1.closer: Very truly yours, P. S. Hench, M. D. psh:ds
